title: AB 2199
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 261.5 of the Penal Code in California defines unlawful sexual intercourse as any act with a minor under 18 years old. The severity of the offense depends on the age difference between the perpetrator and the minor, with penalties ranging from a misdemeanor to a felony. Any person 21 or older engaging in unlawful sexual intercourse with a minor under 16 may face misdemeanor or felony charges, with potential imprisonment for up to four years. If the perpetrator holds a position of authority over the minor, an additional two-year jail term may be imposed. An adult in a position of authority who engages in sexual intercourse with a minor may face civil penalties. Undue influence can include affection, intimidation, coercion, or deceit. An adult engaging in unlawful sexual intercourse with a minor may face civil penalties ranging from $2,000 to $25,000 based on the age difference between them. The district attorney may bring actions to recover civil penalties for unlawful sexual intercourse with a minor. Amounts collected will be deposited in the Underage Pregnancy Prevention Fund for preventing underage pregnancy. A fine of up to $70 may be imposed on individuals who violate a specific section of the Penal Code, with proceeds used according to Section 1463.23. Additionally, a person guilty of certain felony violations involving a minor victim and in a position of authority may face an additional two years of imprisonment. For purposes of this section, a person in a "position of authority" can exercise undue influence over a minor, including through affection, intimidation, coercion, or deceit, and by offering rewards or benefits. No reimbursement required by this act under California Constitution as it pertains to creating, eliminating, or changing penalties for crimes or infractions.
